title.narrative: RightsNow! Strong Communities through Enforcing the Rights of Persons with Disabilities

description.narrative:
Key activities of the RightsNow! project include:
Training: U.S. disability experts and local DPOs coordinate and lead intensive trainings in each country. Disability activists, government, rights attorneys, and other representatives of civil society learn effective strategies for disability rights enforcement and implementation, and develop collaborative plans.Technical assistance: U.S. disability experts and local DPO collaborating organizations provide follow-up technical support for local actions.Exploring the U.S. Model: Representatives from each project country will participate in a professional conference based in Washington D.C. to learn about U.S. models of inclusion and enforcement of legal rights, increase visibility of international leaders, and build international networks. Maintaining an online resource center: The GlobalDisabilityRightsNow.org resource center provides tools, resources, and information to advance the effective implementation and enforcement of national legislation and the CRPD in project countries.

Mobility International USA (MIUSA), with U.S. Consortium partners and in-country service providers, has been implementing the RightsNow! project since 2014.
The goal of the project is to strengthen the implementation and enforcement of disability rights legislation and the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) to protect and promote the rights of persons with disabilities.
The key objectives of RightsNow! are to:strengthen the knowledge and skills of DPOs to promote and advocate for the rights of persons with disabilitiescreate sustainable coalitions between DPOs, CSOs, and governments to advocate for disability rightsshare advocacy experiences through networking and the creation of an online resource center
MIUSA administers the project with a U.S. Consortium of partners: the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund (DREDF); the International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES); and the U.S. International Council on Disabilities (USICD).
